NASA's continued relevance depends upon whether or not its community of scientists, astronauts and overseers are driven by curiosity, imagination and a desire to push the boundaries of our current knowledge and man's place in the universe. 

During NASA's heyday, they recruited the best and brightest of us to achieve their goals. Beating the USSR to the punch was a big part of their focused campaign, of course, but it was more that: the space age ushered in a time of great national pride and excitement, bringing us together in the certainty that we would be the ones to usher in a hopeful future. The whole country looked on in wonder as they relentlessly pursued their ambitious campaign to put man in space.

I feel doubtful that a tired, partisan politician can bring us anywhere close to a NASA resurgence. It's a shame, because our country has never needed a common goal more than we do right now.
